name: And Yet It Moves
description: And Yet It Moves is a puzzle-platformer, set in a unique world, made of ripped paper. Within the paper-collage you can jump, run and last but certainly not least: rotate the world. Learn how to apply the physical consequences of rotation to master the many tricky situations you may encounter.
minimum_requirements: Operating System: Microsoft® Windows® XP / Vista                         Processor: Dual Core 1.6 Ghz or higher, Single Core 2.0 Ghz or higher                         Memory: XP: 512 MB RAM, Vista: 1 GB RAM; (you might need more RAM if you have an integrated graphics card)                         Hard Disk Space: 60 MB                          Video Card: Intel® gma950 or higher; any non integrated card with 128 MB and openGL 1.2 support

reviews.review_text: Surprisingly good.  I seriously didn't expect such a good game when I decided to give it a try, without knowledge about the game at all, with the excepting that it was a puzzle platformer.  It is in my opinion one of the most overlooked indie games I have played, that totally deserves more attention from puzzle platformer fans.  Overall, very good game.

And Yet It Moves is an indie puzzle-platformer, released back when indie puzzle-platformers weren't a commodity yet.  The mechanisms are simple: navigate levels by running, (weakly) jumping and, more importantly, by rotating the level around you. Rotations are made by steps of 90° or 180°. You have to be careful though, because you can only fall from so high before getting crushed to death in the process. And you keep your momentum even after rotating, so don't expect to cheat death by a last-minute rotation.   You will suffer tens or hundreds of deaths, but AYIM remains causal and mostly frustration-free, thanks to infinite lifes and the most generous distribution of checkpoints to ever grace a video game. Which also makes the gotcha-unfair kind of deaths much more tolerable than in other games.  The graphics are made of paper collages and give AYIM a look that remains unique and distinct, even all these years after its release. I sometimes wished for more variety though, as there only are 4 or so 'themes'.  'Music' is made of blip-bloop noisy soundscapes, which works very well but, again, more variety would have been welcome.  Beating the game should take about two hours, and I think that's about tight: the end came just before it would have started getting too repetitive. If you're so inclinded, various modes (speed runs, ...) are available to add replayability, but I think most people will be content to just play through this relatively basic game once.  Overall, AYIM has enough personality to warrant a recommendation. It's certainly much better than what I expected from the 'mixed' Steam user reviews. Because it was offered in several bundles, it lies unplayed in many people's backlog. If that's your case, I encourage you to give it a try. I think it's good enough to recommend a purchase, but there's no question that it's a bit short to justify the non-sale price tag.
Fun and original at the same time. A great 'spin' on the puzzle platformer formula with a distinctive style that any 2D aficionado can appreciate. Worth every penny of its humble price.
This game is an overrated bore. 'How can you say such things?' you ask me. The truth is hard to accept, grasshopper.
A unique game that combines the puzzle and platformer genres along with a beautiful visual style.

I hated this game at first because it seemed like one of those pretentious 'HURR GAMES ARE ART' indie titles, but after giving it a fair chance I found that it was really quite fun. The art direction is impressive, the music and sounds are creative, and it's mostly all-around solid game design. You're not likely to revisit it for years to come, and you'll beat it in a day or two, but And Yet It Moves is a relaxing and simply fun title that's worth picking up if you see it in a bundle or on sale for very cheap.

Remembers all those collages and dioramas you had to make in grade school? Well get ready to experience that sense of texture and weight all over again. AYIM is a relatively simple mechanic made blindingly challenging with irregularly-shaped platforms, noisy physics objects, and a protagonist who has a shockingly realistic resistance to falling from a distance 4 times his height. You will probably get angry at this game, but it is a lot of fun too when you get into a groove.

A unique game that tries new things, and I like that. It's not trying to perfect a pre-existing genre or formula but is experimenting with new ideas. Great art direction, nice gameplay, and ambient sound design.

To me this is a casual game. As others have pointed out the higher achievements and games modes were an afterthought and not many people would delve into these. Thus the game does feel a bit short. I prefer to play this with a controller as it feels more natural for a platformer style game (I didn't play much Jazz Jackrabbit or Commander Keen back in the day) and the trigger buttons are perfect for the rotation mechanic. The puzzles aren't too hard and are all the visual style puzzles that don’t require an explanation. The momentum mechanic is difficult to get used to as it's very easy to pick up too much speed and not be able to land without breaking apart but it is a nice change from the standard 'your character can only jump an x distance before dying'. I recommend this game as a casual game to relax with for a short sitting as that's how I feel it was meant to be played.
Good game, cool music, not worth 10 monies though since it's only about 3 to 3 1/2 hours long.

A very interesting game where you basicly rotate the whole world, which helps you move around the levels. The controls are pretty good, and the physics are alright too, which is good. The only complaint I have is that it's just level after level, with little to no changes to each level (Imagine New Super Mario Bros. series) and little to no changing gameplay. Either way, if you can get through the repetitiveness in this game, you'll enjoy it.

A small, primitive game build around a fascinating game mechanic - the ability to rotate the world to manipulate gravity. The first levels are easy, but quickly romps up the difficulty. Some sound effects are seriously annoying, though, so consider playing it with sound off.

A small, primitive game build around a fascinating game mechanic - the ability to rotate the world to manipulate gravity. The first levels are easy, but quickly romps up the difficulty. Some sound effects are seriously annoying, though, so consider playing it with sound off.

Very, very cool game. Because the levels are comprised of ripped and torn up paper, and even your character is paper, it looks a lot different to almost every game out there, even now, several years after its release, considering a lot of indie games go for the 8-bit look.   This is a very fun game, but it still comes with moments of frustration. The tilting of the screen to move between areas is done pretty well I thought, but there are stages where your timing and approach need to be more than exact, and it can get frustrating dying 20+ times in a row. While it does get repetitive, you're basically doing the same thing the entire game, just walking and rotating the level, it does look really cool and makes for a different game world.   It's a nice little indie game that you can lose yourself in for a bit. If you haven't played it, pick it up, maybe when it's on sale, and give it a go. 7/10
Awesome little game, very addictive, and not so straight-forward as one might think.
and yet ive only played 9 minutes of this ♥♥♥♥ lmao

This is the ultimate indie game. I don't mean indie as in independently developed and published (although that's the case). I mean indie like hipsters before hipsters were hipsters. Back when they were just into indie stuff, I mean. This game is indie because it's a bunch of torn up paper, like the paper bags you used to get your groceries in before you started using canvas bags to be even more sustainable, and especially before someone told you that paper bags actually cause more pollution than plastic bags because they take more energy to produce. And the sound your character makes when he dies is a sort of 'swoosh' sound that some guy makes with his mouth, which is totally indie. In any case this game is pretty great and if you're high because you got some dank nugs, this will either be a great experience or far too complex. Warning: game has bats. Hunter S. Thompson-esque 'Bat Country' experiences are a possibility.
Decent puzzle platformer, but doesn't last very long.

Definitely a game that makes you think. While graphically it may not be as nice looking as the triple A titles out there this game has an artistic look that suits it. It is definitely challenging and while making you angry sometimes it also can make you laugh with some of the wrong choices you make that lead to death. I have to give the maker of this game props for doing something different.

Surprisingly fun. World rotation seems like a gimmick that might get stale quicky, but the game introduces new elements at almost every level to keep things from getting old. The visuals and sound effects are unique and quite funny.

Truly a work of art. As a game, it requires some extra spacial awareness and puzzle-solving skills, on top of platform dexterity and a bit of luck in parts. The visual and audio style is a little odd to me, but it works well as a whole, even when it veers toward creepy or psychedelic. Rotating the world occasionally has surprising effects, several of which must be mastered to finish the game.  Replayability is limited, and the completionist will be annoyed at the insane difficulty of certain (most?) achievements, but the experienced platformer looking for novelty will enjoy this for a few hours.
AYIM, how real pros call it, is a well designed game with a gorgeous soundtrack. What I recommend you is ... to buy it. Now. Or I will kill you.
For those who enjoy this genre, it is an enjoyable game. I think I encountered some bug late in the game that prevented me from finishing it, but that's hopefully fixed now.
Very unique indie game, will challenge you but not overwhelm with complex puzzles. Short and sweet. Get it now in the humblebundle for any price you want.
I have a love/hate relationship with this game. its trippy and creative yet makes you wanna pull your hair out. very enjoyable. don't play if motion sickness is an issue

Well Well Well... It's a game out of the box with an original concept I personnaly never saw before. At the beginning it's confusing to know what keys moves wich way and be aware that it has 0 story wich is a litle bit sad. But! i wasn't bored at all because it was fun to play with the gravity and solve the 'puzzle'. The gameplay is about 3-4 h, hardly recommended :p

A pretty simple platformer with a twist- manipulate the environment around you on a rotational axis. Though the premise is simple, a lot of the puzzles get pretty convoluted, but the game's well-paced difficulty curve never really throws something at you that you can't handle. Be warned, though: there's inconsistent physics on some of the puzzles that can get pretty frustrating.
Something fresh! Wow was going through my games and saw this must of been humble bundle, it is really cool. Rotating puzzles. Art style is pretty cool also.
This is a great game..! play it... short and sweet, just the way i like it :)
Excellent game.  (More or less) orginal game concept with original graphics: a paper collage.
Ok Indie game. Fun at first. Got boring near the end from lack of new mechanics
hipster ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t

Another fun puzzle platformer. Starts off a bit slow (and your character walks a bit slow) but the difficulty and puzzle aspect are really ramped up towards the end. I love the scrapbook style of the art, adds great texture to the game. Definitely a unique puzzle game.

A great little game that is fun to playthrough. The world shifting and puzzle solving mechanics are done quite well and some require quite a bit of thinking in order to complete. The game is short and doesn't have much replay value but for the discounted price it is definitely worth it!

A very unique and visually stunning game to look at. I've had hours of fun on here, and even shared my spot at #1 ghost run on the leaderboards for a good while. The only negative I have with it is that it is too short and too easy! That doesn't take away from the fun and originality though.

A pretty simple platformer with a twist- manipulate the environment around you on a rotational axis. Though the premise is simple, a lot of the puzzles get pretty convoluted, but the game's well-paced difficulty curve never really throws something at you that you can't handle. Be warned, though: there's inconsistent physics on some of the puzzles that can get pretty frustrating.
A really addictive game that grows on you. The paper art style is really charming and different. This is also known as the game where you die a lot.
Pretty good game! Love the level design. wondering about the style though. would've liked to see a bit more orignal artwork for enemies rather than cut and paste pictures of pets.
It's a quaint little game that makes you think outside the box.
This game is just amazing. The atmosphere is great, and yet so strange. Just play it. I highly recommend this game. Play it. Have you played it yet? Play it. 9/10 - Loved it.
Does it move? ♥♥♥♥ yeah it does. Awesome Indie, very unique and will keep you entertained if you tend to do the challenges.  4.5/5
If David Lynch scraped off a few of his braincells and left them under the sun, they would naturally grow into this game.

Only buy this game for someone if you hate them and want them to suffer. And also if you hate yourself.  Jokes on you though I have it already and you can't give it to me again. I got it as part of a Humble Indie Bundle so thankfully I didn't pay full price by any margin.
A trippy ♥♥♥ indie game that'll make you smash your keyboard in frustration in later levels.  9/10, would rage at again.
And yet I recommend.
A very nice tale about stuff that moves
Enjoyable and relaxing platformer. It has challengine parts, but in a calming way.
Great little game.

Fun and interesting platofrmer that relies on you both keeping track of your avatar and your ability to rotate the screen. More a thinking platformer than a twitch based one, altough some levels do require a fiar bit of timing.
Fun and short with interesting music and visuals. I recommend waiting for it to go on sale since the $10 price tag is somewhat high considering how short it is.

And Yet It Moves is a puzzle platformer, where you spin the world around, or the character, depending on how you look at it, to progress through the level. Sadly though the game is not difficult at all, I have managed to beat it a few times over the past few months without even trying to be honest, and with that, the length of the game is very short as well.  The art style is nice, and I really appreciate the sounds here. I especially enjoy the noises your character makes when you fall and break into little pieces of paper. Pttshhhh!  I seem to remember getting this in a bundle a few years ago, so I don't feel as cheated out of my money as I would if I purchased it, but I'd only really recommend picking this up when it drops below 75% off.

This game has a very cool artistic style and interesting mechanics. However, for me, there just isn't enough to justify spending a meaningful amount of money on this title. It feels like it should be on my smart phone so that I literally turn my phone to turn the world. For a PC game its a bit lacking IMO.
it stopped moving  3/10

The premise is interesting but overall as a game it isn't very fun or pleasing to look at. You can flip the world around at will so you can turn a long pit into a sideways hallway and so on and aside from simple puzzles thats really about it. The graphics are not very pleasing and I think its mainly due to the contrast with the player character. Had the player looked different or more consistant in some way with the enviroment it would actually make sense.   I mainly judge games mainly based on its price with the logic being, if each rehash of COD was 10 dollars in my mind each clone would be totally worth it. The asking price of $10 is not worth it and would only recommend if you can get it under $2.

You probably remember feeling frustrated playing some platformers when you were younger; there was always a platform outside of reach, really high up, and you had no idea how you could reach it. You wanted to change the direction of gravity and just GET THERE. Well, 'And Yet it Moves' is an indie platformer with the goal of satiating that appetite for gravity-redirection. It's a simple concept: let the player change the direction of gravity at will, so he can reach those places.     The Good:    * Very interesting graphical style. Everything is handmade and polished with love.  * Innovative gameplay mechanic: you rotate the screen 90 or 180 degrees in either direction, which affects the direction of gravity and the screen rotates so that 'down' is always at the bottom of your screen.  * Relaxing atmosphere. The music is soft and mellow, but does get repetitive after some time.     The Bad:    * The 'genre' of this game is not a platformer as some reviewers might suggest. The genre is 'maze navigation,' and that is unfortunately not a type of game that I personally enjoy.  * I feel like the default controls for rotating the screen are backwards. The right arrow-key should turn the maze clockwise, not anti-clockwise. Fortunately these can be changed in the options menu.  * The camera sometimes zooms very close into the player's avatar (for no reason?) which is VERY FRUSTRATING for a maze-navigation game. It inhibits the player from seeing obstacles from a longer distance.  * The game has 'gotcha' deaths. For example, a random floor may break out from underneath you and kill you. This is not the worst thing given the game's high frequency of save points, but it's still frustrating to suddenly die when you think you're just chillin'.    The Ugly:    * Just not very fun in general. It took me about 30 minutes of playtime to realize this game just wasn't for me.I got to chapter 2, level 2 before I got bored. (There are 3 chapters of about 4 levels each).  * After the 'rotate the world' gimmick fades off, the game is essentially a 'avoid fall damage' simulator. You will try getting around (over?) very simple objects many, many, many times per level without falling to your death. Fall damage is calculated very frustratingly and mysteriously. Because the world rotates around your player, it makes it confusing why your avatar dies after falling from what is realistically only one foot off the ground.    The Verdict:    And Yet it Moves is exactly the reason indie games are indie games: a major developer would have never risked funding a game with this unique gameplay mechanic. I really apprecaite the game for its innovation and risk-taking, but as it turns out, the major developers would have been right not to fund a game like this: rotating the world is simply a gimmick and does not add to the appeal of an otherwise interestingly-looking game. Part of the issue is genre: it simply does not work as a quasi-platformer. I would have liked to see the developer try for a lemmings-style game, or a tower-defense where the creeps always fall 'down' and sending one group to a danger zone my cause another group to drop into where you defenses are weaker. We can be glad that future developers can learn what NOT to do from this game.

Game graphics might not be pleasing to everyone due to it's quite uniqe yet unispired style. Game mechanics are simple yet the game is not - due to constant screen rotations (you might get fuzzy) and no clear indication of what kind of momentum will kill you when you touch the ground. Music is boring and sounds aren't pleasing to hear. Game is medicore at most in a world where are hundrets of great indie games.

Despite having an interesting main mechanic, this game uses the genre of indie game as an excuse for the many frustrating flaws you'll run into. Poor collision shapes matched with a lacking art style and an ability to get stuck in ways you never thought possible will have you understanding why they called the game 'And Yet It Moves', because it's unlikely the moving will be your doing.
The game mechanic is not really that fun. The art is clipart. The music is meh. IDK I got it in a bundle, I tried it, no thank you. No more please.

The full title of this game is 'The developer has no brain, and yet it moves'.   This is a godawful shovelware 2D platformer. Some recognition should be made for them not going down the 'Retro pixel' route that most talentless developers at the bottom of the development ladder take. Instead they decided to attempt actual art, despite being talentless. A bold move which results in predictable disaster.   Shoddy scanned in textures and the most abysmal hand drawn art that makes Napoleon Dynamite look like Leonardo DaVinci assault your eyes in this monsterpiece. I actually had to rinse my eyes out at a chemical spill sink.   Gameplay is woeful. It's a bland platformer with a level rotation mechanic (this is meant to differentiate it from other platformers, but many of those have already tried this). They're not making platformers better, they're making gaming worse. The art is so poor quality it's really hard to control the gameplay because it's distracting.  Technical aspects also plague this game - no 4K support, overscan on fullscreen rendering the game unplayable unless you go into windowed mode if you own a monitor released this decade - it's hard to say if there are any other issues because the graphics are just that bad. I'd rather throw my PC out than play this abomination again.

The artwork is minimalistic and uninteresting. The game play mechanics are annoying, awkward, slow, and unintuitive. The repetitiveness in death is only a replacement for actual game content and game play. The puzzles are like chores, and not actually fun or entertaining. Within fifteen minutes you will grasp and understand the small amount of amusement this game offers, while at the same time growing tired of playing it with each passing minute. It is a lesson in poor game design and lack of creativity. There are barely any sounds nor music. There is no charm, fun, creativity, nor intrigue. And Yet It Moves is another independent showcasing of what game development should steer clear from. It is a cheap, short, flat, unexciting, unexceptional, deficient attempt at game design. There is nothing to see nor experience here. It is a freeware game disguised with an exorbitant asking price from developers who obviously lack shame and humility. And Yet It Moves is inadequate in every fathomable way, and it exemplifies everything that gaming should not be about. There is no actual game content and no game play. It is self-conceited to make up for all of its failures and shortcomings.  And Yet It Moves is mediocre.
actually this game kinda sucked
Buggy and uninovative gravity platformer
I had this demo on the wii for so long and i always wanted this game...now i want my refund

Do you like blind jumps? Not only that, but blind guess work as to what the heck is happening in the rest of the level?   If so, kiss my ♥♥♥, then don't buy this garbage game.  If not, place hand on screen to receive internet high five, then don't buy this garbage game.

Pros:  None  Cons:  -This game wants to make me kill myself (Automatic grounds for one star)  Overall: 1.0/10  I don't ♥♥♥♥ing remember my formatting, and god this game sucks PLEASE STEAM LET ME DELETE IT FROM MY LIBARY
Terrible controls, poor level design, and terribly mismatched graphics combine to make this a game not worth playing at all.
3/5  A simple puzzle-platformer with a well executed world rotating mechanic and a rather unique (if not appealing) ripped paper aesthetic.
Played it only for a short while. While I liked the paper cut-out scenography, the mechanics got old pretty quickly and the game became boring. I do not recommend it.
And yet people pay for this ♥♥♥♥ game
boring

I cannot accurately express how disappointed I was by this title. Clunky control, irritating deaths, unintuitive landing mechanic, aggravating achievements and frankly annoying graphics and sound effects. As someone who habitiually plays games to completion once I've started them, I honestly just don't care about this one. I wish I didn't have to see it on my library.

Boring, unintuitive, uninteresting. It combines platforming with puzzles, and I am not much of a platformer person. Additionally, the artstyle turns me off as well. Can't recommend this game, there's so many like these out there that are more appealing and fun. The whole flipping the whole screen thing just gives me an unecessary headache instead.
what is this
boring
The visual and audio style of this game just do not hook me at all. Even with fiendishly simple controls, this game is infuriatingly confounding.
I hate this game

This is a really weird indie game and I gotta' be honest, I lost interest really fast. It's an interesting concept, but also a one-trick pony from what I saw. There wasn't really that much to keep me interested, unfortunately. So personally, I can't recommend it.

Cute physics based side scroller where the main mechanic is gravity manipulation. Tilt the world to solve puzzles. I found this game very slow, kind of frustrating, and ultimately boring. While the graphics are cute at first, the charm quickly wears off. Music is non-existant. Only play if you're wanting to go to bed afterwards.   4/10
